bibl.title: ‘Y Brenin Llur’, Cwrtmawr ms. 212
bibl.note: ‘Y Brenin Llur’ is transcribed from Cwrtmawr ms. 212 in the National Library of Wales. The manuscript dates to the first half of the eighteenth century. In addition to ‘Y Brenin Llur’, it also includes four tribannau by John Hughes. It also bears the name of David Mor(r)is (Cwrtmawr catalogue, National Library of Wales). The manuscript is damaged and illegible in places, and pages 13-14 are almost entirely missing. There are some original corrections by the scribe. The manuscript is probably a copy of an earlier examplar, and shows some copying errors. For instance, a copying error on page 32 is corrected: diogi, which appears on the following line, was copied, and then deleted and replaced by tylodi.

The text clearly originates from North Wales, perhaps the Conwy or Clwyd valley. The evidence of placenames mentioned in the text, namely caergybi (6.9), crygnant (9.8), traws fynudd (9.11), llandrillo (9.16), and Anglesey (oddyma i fon (9.17)), points in this direction, as does dialect evidence.

The following orthographic and linguistic peculiarites are noteworthy:
extensive confusion of <y> and <u> and of <u> and <i> (not tagged)
modern Welsh /aɪ/ is represented both by <ai> and <ei> (not tagged)
extensive omission of <h> in representing the product of nasal mutation of /p t k/ (not tagged)
pretonic /e/ and /o/ are often reduced to schwa, represented as <y> (partially tagged, but note the very common forms dybyga etc.)
conversely, schwa is sometimes represented as <o> (e.g. conghorwr for cynghorwr (10.11)) (generally tagged)
loss of pretonic /a/, /e/ and /o/, particularly in word-initial position (generally tagged)
appearance of <o> for stressed schwa (e.g. dolwuth for dylwyth (5.7))
/tl/ becomes /kl/ in clws (50.15) (tagged)
epenthetic /t/ or /d/ is found in some cases after /ɬ/ (not tagged)
palatalisation of /g/ (e.g. giamp (23.6), llygied (9.)) (tagged)
extensive use of <w> in place of <wy> (partially tagged)
fairly consistent use of the form pen for pan (not tagged)
subject pronouns ending in /i/ are often written simply as <i> after a verb (e.g. clowsoch i for clywoch chi (9.18)) (not tagged)
the root of the verb canlyn is calyn- (not tagged)
the root of the verb dweud is doud- or doed- (not tagged)
various forms of the root of the verb adnabod are found (e.g. daen- (8.26), doun- (16.29) or dwaun- (27.7); verbnoun dynabod (3.26, 56.14)) (not tagged)
various inflected prepositional forms contain /θ/ (e.g. rhyngthoch (58.9)) (not tagged)
contractions of the aspectual yn plus genitive pronoun are found (e.g. bum ich gwrando (40.2)) (not tagged)
both fo and fe are used as particles / pronouns in front of the verb, although fo is more frequent (not tagged)
in postverbal position, the masculine third-person-singular pronoun is normally o (not tagged)
For further details, see the article in the Transactions of the Honourable Society of Cymmrodorion 2.4 (1843): 417.

editorialDecl.p: Stage directions are variously at the right margin or apparently centred in the manuscript. Both are represented using the <stage> tag in the TEI-transcription, and the position on the page is not represented in the tagging. However, the position is given in a comment in the TEI-file at the relevant point, and this information can therefore be recovered if necessary. At several points, the manuscript contains an ‘X’ in the left margin. This is not represented in the TEI-transcription, but is noted in a comment in the TEI-file and can be recovered if necessary. Note that the TEI-file uses <div type="prologue">, <gap/>, and <trailer> elements. A cast list is supplied.

The corpus editions generate line numbers for the text automatically. Stage directions, names of characters etc. are not assigned line numbers. At several points, an entire line is crossed out in the manuscript, and at another point, an entire stanza is deleted. Note that these lines are assigned line numbers (205, 624-7, and 1243). The number of lines lost in the damaged section of pages 13-14 cannot be assessed easily or with any certainty, and the missing lines have therefore not been assigned line numbers. In a few other cases of missing lines, it is generally possible to establish the number of lines lost and such lines have therefore been given numbers (for instance, 362-3).

langUsage.p: The text is in Welsh, with editorial notes in Welsh and English (including some transcriptions in the International Phonetic Alphabet).
